response.answer_text: I do not know how you can exclude the one's who became president. I am thinking of Theodore Roosevelt who became president after McKinley was assassinated so Roosevelt became president. Teddy Roosevelt was an extraordinary man. Rich as hell but keenly intune with the regular man. He wanted wide reforms of sweat shop worker's caring about their safety. In fact he was rattling the Republicans so much that's why they put him on the ticket to make him go away. Funny how destiny stirs the pot. Likewise Lindon Johnson set up the great society welfare to try and help family's that were struggling. Civil rights, Medicare, Medicaid. Public broadcasting, a call to action on the war on poverty. These 2 men moved mountain's getting their ideas to fruition. Their policy's shaped America. One's a republican and the other a democrat but both extraordinary men not perfect by any means but at the core they cared deeply for their country and it's people.

The nine most influence Veeps: John Adams — It was in his tenure that the Senate established the convention that the Vice President is not part of the discussion and merely casts tie-breaking votes.Thomas Jefferson — He established precedents in the handling of incoming electoral college vote reports. As the first Vice President from a competing party, demonstrated the need for what became the 12th Amendment.Aaron Burr — Established the convention that the Vice President is an independent officer by voting against his own administration in the SenateMartin Van Buren — First Vice President to be a major political advisor to the PresidentJohn Tyler — Established the precedent that when the President dies, the Vice President becomes President, not Vice President Acting as PresidentWalter Mondale — One of the first modern Vice Presidents to be a major advisor to the PresidentAl Gore — Also had a significant role in the administrationDick Cheney — Took on an unprecedented number of portfoliosJoe Biden — Significant advisor to the president

None really. Woodrow Wilson had a vice president that an anarchist tried to kill. his bomb exploded near the veep’s office, but the veep wasn’t hurt. FDR’s last veep, before Truman, Henry Wallace was a near communist who later ran for president on a 3rd party ticket, almost draining enough votes from Truman to let Dewey win. The Chicago paper even published a headline “DEWEY WINS” before final results came in. More recently, we’ve had vice presidents Mondale, Humphrey, Kerry, Gore, all run for president & lose. All Senators too. Kerry going on to also be a Secretary of State involved in the Iran deals. Maybe Kerry wins the prize, for good or bad. Some thought Kerry might run in 2016, but apparently Biden swept everyone away, including Kerry. Biden seems to be in the Humphrey, Mondale, Gore, Kerry mold, another veep running and likely losing too. Nelson Rockefeller was Ford’s vice president. His wealth and name leave a legacy of his ancestor John D. Rockefeller. as well as Nelson’s time as NY Governor.

George H W Bush comes immediately to mind. His two terms as VP cemented his place among Republicans, and a term as President established the family among the nation’s top households. After George (41) stepped down his sons Jeb and George each had successful two-term stints as governor (Florida and Texas respectively) and George 43 went on to win two terms as president. Richard Nixon’s two terms as vice president during the 1950s elevated his status sufficiently that he would become a respected figure in Republican politics, and later win two elections to the White House. Although his career did not create legacy in the fashion that Bush did for his sons, Nixon’s impact on the world stage is arguably more important than those of the Bush presidencies.

Vice President Al Gore stands out among all the Vice Presidents, who never became President. Al Gore’s passion for environmental issues has help made us aware of the ecological disaster. For his achievements he has won a Nobel Peace Prize, an Emmy, an Academy award for best documentary, and a Grammy. Al Gore has written books on the environment starting when he was Senator in 1992, when he published, “Earth in the Balance.” During, the 1992 Presidential election, when Al Gore was the veep candidate on the Democratic ticket, the Republican Presidential candidate, George H.W. Bush, began referring to Gore as “Ozone Man.” Bush’s quip—”Ozone Man”— was a grudging recognition of Gore’s value and impact.

Few VPs who didn't eventually become president are well known today. John C Calhoun is well known for touting nullification while VP under both John Quincy Adams Andrew Jackson. Hubert Humphrey and Walter Mondale were distinguished Senators prior to being VP. Al Gore was a Senator before being VP and since then has become an impassioned voice for recognizing climate change.

My selection as a response to this question would be Thomas Jefferson, Theodore Roosevelt , Franklin Roosevelt, and Harry Truman; however, though the choice of and office of VP has been disparaged by some historians, our country has been lucky to have a large percentage of VPs go on to become strong Presidents (and there are more than just the 4 that I referred to above.
